items.title: Diff does not contain info about type
items.body: Before reworking diff in e14cecc9f27f0d2f80f1444176cc907b2b10f8fb information about the type of the element diff referred to was provided, e.g.  `D` for directories. It makes it difficult to detect when a tracked element was added or removed.

items.title: Issue with Locale: wc.info() issue with XML on working copy
items.body:
I have an issue with quering a working copy.  I thought at first it was a verson issue as the older install was on 0.3.46, the newer one on 1.0.1, however that does not appear to be the case.

Same folder.
1: is in a container (Debian based)
2: in the real file system (Ubuntu)
Note: In reality they are the same folders and files!!

What to do to track down the issue?  Being a container I have limited debug, but I'll see if I can hook it up to pycharm.  Any other ideas?

pysvn 1.0.1
Container - Python 3.7.3
Ubuntu - Python 3.7.5

On both
```python
import os
import svn.local
folder = os.path.abspath(".")
wc = svn.local.LocalClient(folder)
info = wc.info()
```

On Ubuntu (redacted) it works as it should.
--
{'url': 'https://server.com/svn/code', 'relative_url': '^/', 'entry#kind': 'dir', 'entry#path': '.', 'entry#revision': 242, 'repository/root': 'https://server.com/svn/code', 'repository/uuid': '32f932b-a1ee-4af7-9410-dbb59f3b4fd8', 'wc-info/wcroot-abspath': '/var/lib/docker/volumes/jenkins/_data/workspace/test1', 'wc-info/schedule': 'normal', 'wc-info/depth': 'infinity', 'commit/author': 'j', 'commit/date': datetime.datetime(2020, 2, 7, 23, 36, 53, 708195, tzinfo=tzutc()), 'commit#revision': 242, 'entry_kind': 'dir', 'entry_path': '.', 'entry_revision': 242, 'repository_root': 'https://server.com/svn/code', 'repository_uuid': '32f932b-a1ee-4af7-9410-dbb59f3b4fd8', 'wcinfo_wcroot_abspath': '/var/lib/docker/volumes/jenkins/_data/workspace/test1', 'wcinfo_schedule': 'normal', 'wcinfo_depth': 'infinity', 'commit_author': 'j', 'commit_date': datetime.datetime(2020, 2, 7, 23, 36, 53, 708195, tzinfo=tzutc()), 'commit_revision': 242}

On Container it breaks inside wc.info()
--

items.title: "non-existent in revision" When listing recursively
items.body:
Hello,

I have been using your code quite a bit. There seems to be something wrong with the way that the `recursive` option works with the `list_recursive` function however. I am getting a strange error that some of the items attempting to be listed don't exist.

Moreover, the items that are listed are mostly all incorrectly listed as files, not directories. Not sure if it is a bug?

The `svn` repo that I am pulling from is listed here:

https://svn.blender.org/svnroot/bf-blender/tags/blender-2.78-release/lib/

It contains source code for the program Blender 3d.

I am trying to query the directories nested within but get errors almost right away. Here is an example:
```python
>>> from svn.remote import RemoteClient
>>> myclient = RemoteClient("https://svn.blender.org/svnroot/bf-blender/tags/blender-2.78-release/lib/")
>>> for item, info in myclient.list_recursive(): print(item)
```

```
 ... 
darwin-9.x.universal
python
win64
win64_vc12
windows

    do_combine=True)
```

items.title: local client can not support delete operation.
items.body: It can't delete directory with local client when I want update old files.

items.title: Bug: diff fails on files with non-UTF-8 encodings (e.g. Latin-1 encoding)
items.body:
In common.py, method `diff(self, old, new, rel_path=None)` has a bug in line 457:
`  for non_empty_diff in filter(None, diff_result.decode('utf8').split('Index: ')):`
Here silently UTF-8 encoding is assumed. But this fails for non UTF-8 files (e.g. for files with Latin-1 (= ISO 8859-1) encoding):

Traceback (most recent call last): 
File "D:/TEMP/SVN/comparison/GetLines.py", line 6, in Difference = l.diff(6382, 6383) 
File "C:\Python35\lib\site-packages\svn\common.py", line 447, in diff 
	for non_empty_diff in filter(None, diff_result.decode('utf8').split('Index: ')): 
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xda in position 396852: invalid continuation byte

Although not a full solution, but helpful might be to add an extra parameter for specifying the encoding, which defaults to utf8.

`def checkout():`
`    r = svn.remote.RemoteClient('path', username='username', password='password')`
`    r.checkout('/4.9.5')`

`ClassName.checkout()`

and run it, but it raise an SvnException: Command failed with (1): ['svn', '--non-interactive', '--username', 'username', '--password', 'password', '--no-auth-cache', 'checkout', 'path', '/4.9.5']
b"svn: E000013: Can't make directory '/4.9.5': Permission denied\n"

items.title: nose is not required for svn to work but mentioned in install_requires
items.body: It would be better if test requirements were separated from install requirements to not to have to install unnecessary dependencies. And it would be better if ``nose`` requirement moved from ``requirements.txt`` to ``tox.ini`` or ``test-requirements.txt`` for example or otherwise separated from dependencies required for ``svn`` to work.

items.title: remote_info entry_revision vs commit_revision
items.body:
When running the svn command line client against a repo URL, I get:

```
Path: Config
URL: https://<root_url>/.../Config
Relative URL: .../Config
Repository Root: <root_url>
Repository UUID: c6c330d0-ed96-11df-a23f-a1aa3014a860
Revision: 1775750
Node Kind: directory
Last Changed Author: <author>
Last Changed Rev: 1616232
Last Changed Date: 2017-10-20 19:29:39 +0200 (Fr, 20 Okt 2017)
```

`Revision` is the HEAD repo revision, the 'Last Changed Rev' refers to the revision of the path 'Config' that I requested info for.

PySvn returns this:
```
'entry_revision' (139902232167152) = {int} 1775765
'commit_revision' (139902232121072) = {int} 1616232
```
I think the name `entry_revision` is misleading. It should be repo_revision.
What do you think?

items.title: Releasing a version with svn update and other nice, new features
items.body:
Looks like you added support for svn update and other commands a couple weeks after the release of 0.3.44. Any plan to release these new features? They'd be really useful. For now, I can call run_command to do the svn update, but would prefer to do it the "right" way.

Thanks for writing this. It's incredibly nice to have a Python svn package that works in a virtualenv and doesn't need to be installed as a system package.

items.title: Customizing Environment at Constructor
items.body:
Hey @dsoprea,

As mentioned by @daa [here](https://github.com/dsoprea/PySvn/pull/71#issuecomment-250448636), what are your viewpoint on customizing environment at client constructor using `kwargs`?

items.title: shell environment gets wiped out in CommonClient.runCommand
items.body:
https://github.com/dsoprea/PySvn/blob/master/svn/common.py#L55

This line sets the shell's environment to _only_ LANG=...

It would be nice if the parent shell's environment could be preserved and only the LANG variable overwritten. As it is, this line makes `ssh-agent` unusable with this library.

items.title: DNS resolution not working
items.body:
When I checkout using this library then this code in common.py returns an error:

```
p = subprocess.Popen(cmd,
                             stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stderr=subprocess.STDOUT,
                             env={'LANG': 'en_US.UTF-8'})

 stdout = p.stdout.read()
     r = p.wait()
      if r != success_code:
         raise SvnException("Command failed with (%s): %s\n%s".format(
              (p.returncode, cmd, stdout)))
```

stdout contains:
`svn: E731001: Unable to connect to a repository at URL 'svn://dummydomain.corp/repos/testing/robot-
 framework-test/trunk'
svn: E731001: Unknown hostname 'dummydomain.corp'`

Invoking the very same command specified by 'cmd' manually in a shell works.

I think the problem is that the Popen call is using the parameter env and therefore effectively completely replacing the environment with the single variable 'LANG'.
I could fix the problem by just not using the env parameter:
`p = subprocess.Popen(cmd,
                             stdout=subprocess.PIPE,
                             stderr=subprocess.STDOUT)`

As a sidenote:
This does not produce a valid error string:
`raise SvnException("Command failed with (%s): %s\n%s".format(
                (p.returncode, cmd, stdout)))`
I think you cannot mix %s-syntax with format.

items.title: Advantages over PySvn
items.body:
Hey @dsoprea 

I was planning to add helpdoc in `README.md` or maybe host it via `github.io`, where we explain why our PySvn is better than [Pysvn](http://pysvn.tigris.org/). I searched for this because the earlier Pysvn which I was using causes a lot of issues while setting up. Some of the rants of developers facing issues are: 
- https://www.reddit.com/r/Python/comments/22q6gc/this_is_why_i_hate_pysvn/ 
- http://stackoverflow.com/a/25984096/1799475 

This would do 2 things: 
- It would make clear why to have our Pysvn when the old Pysvn is already there
- What benefits does our Pysvn provide over the old Pysvn

which would in-turn lead to more adaptability of our PySvn. What do you think about this?  

Thanks

items.title: suggestions: --force as an option to export
items.body:
export with --force is not possible
changed common.py:296 to

```
    def export(self, to_path, revision=None, force= False):
        cmd = []

        if revision is not None:
            cmd += ['-r', str(revision)]

        cmd += [self.__url_or_path, to_path]
        cmd.append('--force') if force else None
        self.run_command('export', cmd)

```

items.title: Creation of Test Suite
items.body:
Hey @dsoprea 

What do you think about forming a test suite for PySvn ? I can contribute for that if other maintainers can pitch in. 

Thanks

items.title: Unable to differentiate between SVN command failing and other errors
items.body:
The library raises a `ValueError` when the SVN CLI client fails. This exception is very common, and can be raised for a number of reasons. As a result, it is difficult for the caller to distinguish between the SVN CLI client failing and other issues.

Please change the exception type, for example to a subclass of `ValueError` for backward compatibility. I've sent in a pull request (#43) for this.

items.title: Please document that this is a wrapper for the CLI svn client
items.body: This library just wraps the `svn` commandline client, executing it using `subprocess`. In my opinion, this should be documented in the README, as it has implications for performance (each command needs to execute `svn`, which has to re-establish a HTTPS connection, etc.) as well as deployment (the machine the code runs on needs the `svn` CLI client).

items.title: Support for Diff
items.body:
Hey

Can we make it to support `svn diff` ? 

Thanks

items.title: license
items.body:
Hi,

I'm working on a library @https://github.com/tony/libvcs/ that could utilize this project for richer functionality.  However there is a snag I found that the current license on pysvn conflicts with libvcs (BSD).

Any thoughts on making this license compatible with MIT/BSD?

items.title: six version requirement
items.body:
I've just installed svn 0.3.38 on Python 2.7 using pip. It downgraded my version of six from 1.8.0 to 1.7.2. The current version on PyPI is 1.10.0.

Would you please consider changing requirements.txt to have six>=1.7.2

I have no immediate problem but if some other package makes the same call to use a fixed version of six then there could be a clash. The same goes for python-dateutil.

It is good for applications to use fixed versions in their requirements but libraries ought to be more flexible.

items.title: ValueError when URL not found
items.body:
When trying to access a RemoteClient on a non-existent repo, it throws a slightly odd ValueError. This would be easier to handle errors correctly if this threw a more specific SvnError or SvnUrlNotFoundError or similar.

import svn.remote
r = svn.remote.RemoteClient("https://plugins.svn.wordpress.org/gravityforms/trunk")
r.checkout("gravity")

> Traceback (most recent call last):
>  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
>  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/svn/remote.py", line 20, in checkout
>    self.run_command('checkout', cmd)
>  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.4/dist-packages/svn/common.py", line 46, in run_command
>    (p.returncode, cmd, stdout))
> ValueError: Command failed with (1): ['svn', '--non-interactive', 'checkout', 'https://plugins.svn.wordpress.org/gravityforms/trunk', 'gravity']

items.title: CommonClient.default_log fails with KeyError if LogEntry doesn't contain a 'msg' Child
items.body:
The current implementation of 'CommonClient.default_log' assumes that each 'logentry' always contains 'msg', 'author', and 'date' Elements in the XML output of svn log command.

I do have access to an svn repository where some few revisions don't contain 'msg' Elements.
(Perhaps this repository is corrupted, but I don't have administrator access to the svn repositoty to check it.)

It would be helpfull to provide default value '' to all fields of 'entry_info' in order to prevent a KeyError in
common.py, line  203 in such situation.

items.title: type str doesn't  support the buffered api split('\n')
items.body:
I'm using python 3.3,  when I use a RemoteClient to list entries in a repository via file protocol , It reports the error "type str doesn't  support the buffered api split('\n')"

It seems that in this case , the stdout object in run_command function turns to be an bytes object, so  it should be decode to an str object.   So I add " stdout = stdout.decode('utf-8') ", it seems works fine in my case . But I'm not sure does the 'utf-8' suit for all cases.

items.title: In some cases, there's no author node in commit_node
items.body:
In some cases, there's no authority request for commit, in this case , the command 'list' 's result doesn't has an 'author' node in the 'commit'  info .
So in this case the line 255  "author = commit_node.find('author').text" will report an "NoneType has no attribute text" error.
